entry.et: Middle English suken, from Old English sūcan; akin to Old High German sūgan to suck, Latin sugere

def.dt: :to draw (as liquid) into the mouth through a suction force produced by movements of the lips and tongue sucked milk from his mother's breast
:to draw something from or consume by such movements suck an orange suck a lollipop
:to apply the mouth to in order to or as if to suck out a liquid sucked his burned finger
:to draw by or as if by suction when a receding wave sucks the sand from under your feet Kenneth Brower inadvertently sucked into the … intrigue Martin Levin
:to take in and consume by or as if by suction a vacuum cleaner sucking up dirt suck up a few beers opponents say that malls suck the life out of downtown areas Michael Knight
:to draw something in by or as if by exerting a suction force
:to draw milk from a breast or udder with the mouth
:to make a sound or motion associated with or caused by suction his pipe sucked wetly flanks sucked in and out, the long nose resting on his paws Virginia Woolf
:to act in an obsequious manner when they want votes … the candidates come sucking around W. G. Hardy usually used with up sucked up to the boss
:to be objectionable or inadequate our lifestyle sucks Playboy people who went said it sucked H. S. Thompson
:to make the effort required to do or deal with something difficult or unpleasant
:to contract, flatten, and tighten (the abdomen) especially by inhaling deeply
:a person who is ingratiating or fawning a suck–up to the teacher
